bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Philip Perry, March 2, 1732

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchant Philip Perry, March 2, 1732, brother to and partner of Micajah Perry, to comment the need for a tailor for the Burwell estates, on tobacco sales, and on the debts of the Page estate to the recently deceased merchant John Pratt.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Philip Perry, March 2, 1732

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
March 2d, 1732
Mr. Philip Perry

div1.p:
By this conveyance I have already writ
pretty largely to your brother Mr. Alderman however having received various
Letters from you I shall think it proper to give you a Short entertain
ment.

In your of the 27th. of July you give me hopes
of procuring a taylor for Mr. Burwells Estate and in answer a . . . which I shall be glad
you Succeed in we have always been Supply'd in by You hitherto altho
he were one of an inferiour rank he might Serve to make up Servants
cloths As to the Servant I writ for on Accot of Colonel Pages affairs
a proper Well dispos'd Person that could write a good hand
and had some Small knowledge in Surgery such as I have met with
in Barbers boys would be of great Use in that estate I had the luck
some years agoe to get one of this Sort at the rate of £5. Per annum
but how to Limit you I cannot tell I should not think it proper to
exceed £8" Per annum the highest wages I think that you have sent
any Taylor was 7£ or 8£. it may not be amiss here to Acquaint You
the Shoemaker that came away in Loney one of his Convicts which You
recommended to my favour dyed in his passage else I should not have
endeavour faild to use my endeavour to [illegible] answer your desire

In yours of the 10 of November is included
the steps you had taken in the sales of my tobo Last Year 12 of the [tobacco mark]
by Malbon Sold at 8 1/4 and 22 of the [tobacco mark] by do Ship at the same price
they were all stemm'd tobo and your brother speaks in favour of the
goodness of the first mark I shall not complain of this mean sale
but Allow me to tell you a story I met with this very day a Neigh
bour of mine sends 38 hhds. of stemmd in a ship that did not sail so soon as Malbon to Mr. Forward which I cannot
beleive under better management than mine Was 22 of them are Sold
the top sort at 9 1/2 d the middling at 9 d. and the luggs at 81/2 d he is a new
broom indeed but by the pleasing accounts he sends to his Customers
he engroses a great many consigments he hath now three ships
in his interest and how can you blame men for running into him
upon this great difference in prizes he finds ways to give them

Your letter directed to the Exrs of Colo Page about Mr. Pratts affairs tells us
you had given Account by the Dolphin bound to Nancimond of his death
This letter never came to hand that I know of another of the 24th of July by Lony I suppose is much to the same purpose

You tell us in Mr. Prat's books Colo Page stood indebted upon his own
Accot 164"7"6 and as Attorney for Mr. Prat 189"7"1 I cannot take
upon me to answer to these things till I meet the Secretary I believe no
thing of All this appears from Colo Pages books or papers which I must
let
you know appear to be kept in a very Confus'd negligent manner but more of
this another time We shall endeavour to give you the best light
we Can into this affar and conclude at present

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Letter book, 1731 July 9-1732 July 13 , Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia. There is a nineteenth-century copy of this letter in the Minor-Blackford Papers, James Monroe Law Office and Museum, Fredericksburg, Virginia.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.

[1] Philip Perry (1703-1762) was partner with his brother Micajah III in the family business after the death of their father Richard in 1720 and grandfather Micajah in October 1721. (Price. Perry of London. . . . pp. 24-27.)

[2] The Forward was a London ship of 150-200 tons commanded in1728-29 by William Loney, and in 1731 by George Buckridge. (Survey Report 6800 summarizing Adm. 68/194 and Survey Report 6801 summarizing Adm 68/195, Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia. )

[3] The Rebecca was probably a London ship; she was of 300 tons, had a crew of 11, and was commanded by Samuel Malbon in 1731-32. (Adm. 65/195, found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)

[4] "The lowest grade [of tobacco] was known as lugs as early as 1686. . . ." (Philip A. Bruce. Economic History of Virginia in the Seventeenth Century: An Inquiry into the Material Condition of the People, Based on Original and Contemporaneous Records. [New York: MacMillan and Co., 1896]. p. 422 online at "Classics of American Colonial History." http://www.dinsdoc.com/bruce-1-1.htm)
[5] John Pratt was a London merchant and an old friend of Carter's who usually referred to him as "Daddy."
[6] The Nansemond is a tributary of the James River flowing into it on the south side of Hampton Rhoads along the west side of present-day Suffolk.
